title: Citi and Aprenda Reward Formal Microenterprise in Peru
summary: Lima - Once more, the Citi Foundation and Aprenda-Grupo ACP's Microenterprise Institute-recognized the extraordinary contributions of formal microenterprises to the nation's economy by honoring eight outstanding Peruvian entrepreneurs in the eleventh annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards (PREMIC).
tag-1: Citi and Aprenda Reward Formal Microenterprise in Peru
tag-3: Lima – Once more, the Citi Foundation and Aprenda—Grupo ACP's Microenterprise Institute—recognized the extraordinary contributions of formal microenterprises to the nation's economy by honoring eight outstanding Peruvian entrepreneurs in the eleventh annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards (PREMIC).
tag-4: "PREMIC is part of Citi's commitment to promote the growth of formal microenterprises that not only succeed economically but also contribute to community development," explained Mario Farren, Citi Country Officer for Peru. "The awards also recognize the work of the financial institutions that make credit available for entrepreneurs seeking to grow their businesses."
tag-5: Offered in Peru since 2005, this international Citi Foundation initiative has honored 106 microentrepreneurs—all clients of local financial institutions—and awarded them more than 1 million soles to invest in their businesses.
tag-6: "PREMIC recognizes the ability of microentrepreneurs to overcome adversity and the challenges of establishing a formally constituted business in Peru. We reward their initiative and innovation while highlighting the role microfinance institutions play in making such businesses succeed," commented Ricardo de la Piedra, Aprenda's General Manager.
tag-8: The top award, for "PREMIC Entrepreneur of the Year" – went to Dr. Alvaro Sante Alvarado from Chala District (Caravelí, Arequipa), who opened a clinic to provide quality health services to local residents. Thanks to a loan from Caja Arequipa, Alvaro was able to expand his clinic and diversify his services to provide care for rural inhabitants and hold free preventive care campaigns in Chala and surrounding areas.
tag-9: First prize in the Retail category was awarded to María Oscanoa – a client of Caja Huancayo in Junín – who sells maca-derived products at her minimarket, "Maca Market Junín." After noticing that maca was being exported but not consumed locally despite its health benefits, María saw the opportunity to start a business that would benefit the community. The second-place winner in the same category was Grennady Mamani – a client of Caja Arequipa in Puno – a 29-year-old who runs a wool and leather production and commercialization business that ensures fair prices and market access for families that raise sheep and llamas.
tag-10: Taking home first prize in the Production category was Carlos Urbina Cuya, a client of Caja Huancayo in Lima. After retiring from the Navy, Urbina started his own bottled water business, "Agua Woda." At the age of 74, he sells his product to companies and private customers. Nimio Yupán Francia of Cerro de Pasco (Pasco) came in second for his coffee production company. Thanks to a loan from Financiera Confianza, Francia has been able to make his "Monreal" brand of coffee available in Lima.
tag-11: The Services category was led by Alfredo Di Natale (Lima), who runs three Arthur Murray dance schools. A client of Banco de Crédito, he is a three-time national marinera dance champion who returned to Peru after 20 years abroad to open an Arthur Murray franchise here. The second-place winner in this category was Alejandro Réquez, a client of Banco Financiero, who has a ceramics silk-screening business in Lima. Alejandro, who is originally from Ancash province, was honored for his extraordinary history of entrepreneurship, dedication to learning, proactivity and providing employment opportunities for people with disabilities.
tag-12: Finally, Erika Rosario Salluca (aged 24) – a client of Caja Arequipa in Moquegua – won special mention as "Young Entrepreneur" of the year for her perseverance in starting a frozen treat company using local fruits. "Las Chicas del Raspado" started out with one table and an improvised ice cream machine; today, it is formal business thanks to Erika's savings habits and the financing she has received.
tag-14: PREMIC also included an award for "Most Innovative Financial Institution," an honor that went to Banco Financiero for its "Entrepreneur" program giving access to credit to people as young as 18 with only 3 months of business experience. The program includes a psychometric study to determine the applicant's capacity for payment and project management. Banco Financiero will receive two scholarships for its executives to attend the Boulder Institute of Microfinance's prestigious Microfinance Training Program for Latin America and the Caribbean in 2017.
tag-15: All references to Citi should be understood to mean Citibank del Perú S.A.

tag-18: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation works to promote economic progress in communities around the world and focuses on initiatives that expand financial inclusion. We collaborate with best-in-class partners to create measurable economic improvements that strengthen low-income families and communities. Through a "More than Philanthropy" approach, Citi's business resources and human capital enhance our philanthropic investments and impact. For more information, visit www.citifoundation.com.
tag-19: Aprenda Aprenda, Instituto de la Microempresa, part of Grupo ACP, specializes in providing access to small business education. Through its own initiatives and in partnership with private companies and international organizations, Aprenda designs and implements business promotion and development projects that encourage entrepreneurship and competitiveness in the microenterpreneurial and SME sector. To date, more than 800,000 entrepreneurs and business owners in Peru have participated in Aprenda programs and events. For more information, please visit www.aprenda.com.pe
